quizzes.question: Select the correct parameters for radial gradient.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Radial Gradients [/h1]

To create a radial gradient, you must define at least [b]two color stops[/b]. 
The radial gradient is defined by its [b]center[/b].

The CSS syntax of the radial gradient looks like this: [code format="css" ]background: radial-gradient([b]position[/b], [b]shape or size[/b], [b]color-stops[/b]);[/code]
The [b]first value[/b] defines the gradient position. We can use a descriptive keyword, such as top, bottom, center, or left; or we can specify, for example, 50% 50% to set the gradient at the center or 0% 0% to set the gradient to start at top left.

The [b]second value[/b] defines the shape and the gradient size. There are two arguments to shape gradients: The first is the [b]ellipse, which is the default[/b]; and the second is the  [b]circle[/b].
[note]Lastly, the [b]third value[/b] defines the color combination.[/note]

quizzes.question: What is the default value for the "shape" parameter?
Which choice is not an acceptable value for "position" parameter?

Add a circular radial gradient to produce black and red colors, with color-stops accordingly at 20 pixels and 70 pixels.
[!raw!]
background: radial-gradient
   (circle, black {0}px, red {1}px);
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Setting the Color Stops[/h1]

As with linear gradients, a color stop is specified with a color, plus an optional stop position, which is a length or percentage value.

Here's a simple circular gradient with color stops:[code format="css" codeId="607"]background: -moz-radial-gradient(circle, green 40%, yellow 50%, blue 70%); [/code]
